text: stop stop it hi everyone a literal
five-year-old here the internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of this self-titled album from
zeal and arter for the uninitiated
zealand arter is an avant-garde metal
band spearheaded by swiss american
songwriter and multi-instrumentalist
manuel genu whose work started creating
a buzz around 2016 when people began
stumbling across what would be his
breakout album which was super rough
around the edges production wise but
still a lot of listeners including
myself were blown away by the fact that
this was a legit music project fusing
together elements of black metal and
slave spirituals which again unlikely
combination but absolutely no joke
especially as manuel went on to release
the record stranger fruit in 2018 a
project that in a lot of ways was
working off the same basic premise but
brought its full potential to bear like
not only was the production on this
thing heavy and crushing and colorful
and dynamic but on top of that the way
these gospel and blues and soul-inspired
vocals just soared over the sinister
black metal chord progressions it
sounded so good it should have been
illegal and that's before even getting
into the ways this record creatively
explored themes of societal racism and
bigotry the fears and horrors of living
that experience especially in a
pre-civil rights era so yeah in my
opinion this thing was one of the best
records of that year easily it was
eventually followed up with the wake of
a nation ep which featured tracks in
response to the police brutality and the
death of george floyd which sparked
global protests in 2020 and as good as
zealand arter has been so far i just had
this feeling that you know maybe things
are just getting started the best is yet
to come because there's so much creative
potential in the genre fusions that
manuel brings to the table through this
project especially on a self-titled
record where this might be an
opportunity for zealand arter to really
perfect or define their sound ultimately
however after multiple listens i have to
say i think this is the weakest offering
this band has brought to the table thus
far and by a pretty wide margin too so i
feel this way for a couple key reasons
starting with the vocals man the singing
on zealand artor's last record was so
[ __ ] good with manuel much of the
time sounding like a vengeful fire and
brimstone type preacher barking like a
demon dog sometimes digging down into
the guttural growl range of like a tom
waits the soulful cleans on this lp were
great as were the traditional black
metal style vocals as well the singing
just proficient all around now i think
the vocal approach on this new lp is in
a similar ballpark but it's changed
enough to where i think the tone of the
music of the performances is noticeably
different there are moments on this
thing where i feel like manuel isn't so
much plugging directly into
these melodic phrasings coming from
blues or from spirituals and it sounds
more like a dude trying to aggressively
croon his way through a bad eddie vetter
impression i'm a golden liar
weirdly enough there's a lot of new
metal camp on this record as well that i
don't think goes over all that great
like the muttered intro vocals on the
track i caught you which
sounds like something off of an early
corn record maybe even limp bizkit like
in a way i can hear what manuel is going
for on this lp but it still comes off
like an aesthetic misfire like the song
bow for example which i think continues
to
walk down the group's unique bridge
between spirituals and metal music and
does so with pounding drums and
relatively haunting background vocals
some huge hits of gurgling bass
distortion as well but it all builds up
into this rocking outro with a massive a
group refrain bow down to the american
way
bow down to the american way
which given zealand arter's history is
obviously said in a mocking way like the
messaging on this track is coming from a
good place
don't cry for the weak and neglected go
blind in the cage we erected stand tall
with the rage of a storm now kill hope
for the age because we know how like the
systematic cycle of
violence and oppression and then outrage
that the track is painting lyrically is
accurate and uh quite horrifying
instrumentally and and even vocally at
points it feels like the thing it is
satirizing it sounds like what it's
trying to attack i i think i could blast
parts of this song at a trump rally and
like it would get the fists pumping
there's also the track golden liar which
was a lead single to this thing where
the lonely rustic electric guitars and
the whistling in the background combined
with the overly passionate lead vocals
it just sounds like a music bed for a
pickup truck commercial even more
absurdly out of bounds is the track
immersion which doesn't really provide
much else other than the silly contrast
between
these totally throttling aggressive
heavily compressed black metal passages
and these glistening little beats that
sound like uh the start of a freaking
owl city song and this is not the only
part on this record where the band's
once thrilling genre combinations
now feels like a zany switcheroo that
you might get on a record that mike
patton is on but in this instance it
doesn't quite land like the song jmb
where suddenly we start getting all of
these uh weirdly slick and sweet prague
jazz guitar passages then there's the
instrumental closer which legitimately
sounds like slowed in reverb lincoln
park from the 2000s generally i think a
lot of the rifts on this thing have
drifted away from the harmonic and
melodic nuances of the black metal that
has consistently inspired zealand arter
up until this point and don't get me
wrong like that genre is still here
at points in notes like you can pick up
on it on the song hold your head low
maybe that's the biggest most shining
example here but again this isn't how
the drum and guitar work plays out on
this lp much of the time a lot of tracks
on this thing just feature the overly
compressed regimented chunkiness that
you might get on the guitars from an
industrial metal record you can hear it
on the song feed the machine things even
get a little gently i would say on the
song death to the holy and while this
isn't the worst thing in the world i
think it's a more one-dimensional move
especially since on this lp it leads to
a lot of basic forgettable generic
binary riffs
now i also want to quickly mention the
overt satanism on this lp which uh
generally in metal music
i don't have an issue with uh there's a
lot of satanically themed metal tracks
and lps that i love that i hold near and
dear in fact it's not really a new topic
for this project it's cropped up on
previous records and tracks but i can
say in regards to past works there was
at least like layers to it or it played
into a larger narrative or its
incorporation was subtler whereas on
church burns for example it doesn't
really seem to be informed by anything
else other than
the edge it's just a very thinly veiled
attempt at being uh like a provocateur i
guess
ooh i'm such a naughty boy burning this
church dad's gonna be mad at you
sure you could say this track does have
a very visceral performance and uh
pairing this kind of messaging with a
vocal style that is at least somewhat
gospel inspired that does bring
something to the table but i'd argue not
as much as stranger fruit did which
maybe brings me to my biggest general
issue with this lp and it's that it
feels like
a simpler
louder but also more watered-down
version of what i've enjoyed from this
project in the past sure this thing does
feature some very aggressive noisy and
and hard-hitting moments here and there
but my enjoyment doesn't really extend
past the thrill of hearing these parts
maybe for a couple of times and then
their you know impact wears off just a
bit pushing past that there's very
little about uh the writing both
lyrically and melodically the song
structuring the genre combinations or
even in a lot of ways the production
that i'm all that crazy about and once
again the record is packed with these
moments that uh feel almost zany a
little cringy kind of random in a way
that's uh working against the darkness
and evil and mystique that it's
obviously trying to portray in its more
serious and more legitimate spots so
yeah unfortunately as much as i have
enjoyed zealand arter's stuff in the
past this record just did not do it for
me at all like on the whole i didn't
really
enjoy this
not even like a little feeling a light
to decent four on this one tran position
have you given this record a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and

anthony fantano
zealand arter
forever
